Antonio Salieri.Action: His valet and cook show concern and care by bringing him sugared cakes and trying to coax him out of isolation.
Old Salieri isolated, locked himself in, pleading for mercy and forgiveness, indicating internal torment and social withdrawal.
Locks himself in a room and cries out desperately for forgiveness, showing mental turmoil and lack of control.
Has loyal servants (valet and cook) attending him attentively, indicating some maintained status and organizational ability even in old age.
Publicly confesses guilt and asks Mozart for forgiveness.
Publicly confesses guilt and reveals his inner torment loudly and dramatically.
Despite mental anguish, manages to orchestrate a memorable public scene that draws attention.
Looks at the valet in contempt and shuts the window with a bang, ignoring the people outside.
Looks at the valet in contempt and shuts the window with a bang, refusing interaction.
Stares silently and causes concern in servants and onlookers due to his unresponsiveness and eventual bleeding behind a locked door.
Refuses to engage with the chaplain, responds curtly and dismissively to offers of conversation and care.
Sits alone in hospital, ignores attempts at sincere outreach by Father Vogler.
Is found in a hospital after a suicide attempt, showing a severe personal and psychological crisis.
Wears the Civilian Medal and Chain awarded by the Emperor, indicating previous official recognition and high status.
Engages minimally and dismissively with Father Vogler, refusing to communicate or show remorse openly.
Engages the priest Vogler in conversation despite his own pain and state, sharing his music and memories.
Refuses to seek forgiveness or confess despite Vogler's repeated offers and concern.
Displays pride in his past achievements with some enthusiasm while recounting his popular compositions.
Plays a melody slyly to engage the priest, smiles at shared recognition.
Engages in a candid conversation about Mozart, shows eagerness and openness.
Pauses reflecting deeply before confessing feelings of guilt.
Declares Mozart was cruelly murdered with a tone of pain and innocence.
Slyly plays the opening measure of Mozart's Eine Kleine Nachtmusik to demonstrate his knowledge of Mozart's work.
Engages in a serious and intense dialogue with the priest about Mozart's death, showing self-awareness and emotional depth.
Appears lost in a private world during conversation, indicating a moment of internal struggle or distraction.
Turns with an expression of extreme innocence when confronted about Mozart's murder, showing a skilled use of demeanor to influence perception.
Expresses jealousy not towards Mozart himself but towards Mozart's father for teaching him everything.
Reveals intimate and vulnerable feelings about his own father's lack of support and misunderstanding of his musical passion.
Reflects on his jealousy of Mozart's prodigious talent and his father's disapproval of his musical ambitions.
Makes a solemn vow to dedicate his life to becoming a great composer, showing seriousness, humility, and commitment.
Expresses grand ambitions of fame and immortality through music, revealing confidence and clear self-directed goals.
Worked hours every day teaching students, many of them for free, sitting on endless committees to help poor musicians.
Describes himself as a model of virtue, keeping his hands off women and working tirelessly.
Expresses pride in being liked by everyone and liking himself.
Views his opportunities and achievements as a divine acceptance of his vow.
Studies under Gluck, a great composer, and learns everything he knows.
Introduced personally to Emperor Joseph and becomes the Emperor's court composer within a few years.
Plays duets with the Emperor, corrects the Emperor’s royal sight-reading, demonstrating high skill and confidence.
Keeps a vow of virtue, works long hours teaching and serving on committees, showing dedication and discipline.
Acknowledges the Emperor has no ear for music but continues to please him and maintain position.
Moves respectfully through a crowd, receives bows from young men; quietly observes others while playing a game to guess Mozart's identity.
Follows a servant carrying pastries, drawn by a simple delight.
Recognizes the importance of the event and attends the concert at the Archbishop's residence to observe Mozart's work.
Plays a mental game assessing Mozart's extraordinary early achievements and questions how talent manifests outwardly.
Distracted and leaves the main room following a servant with pastries, momentarily abandoning focus on the concert and the occasion.
Sneaks into the buffet room to steal a pastry, hides to avoid being seen.
Observes Mozart and Constanze’s playful interaction with astonishment but does not intervene or join.
Sneaks into the buffet room cautiously to avoid being noticed by the servant.
Looks about cautiously before reaching for the chocolate balls.
Ducks down behind the pastry table immediately upon hearing approaching footsteps to avoid detection.
Shows no direct involvement or reaction to Mozart's absence in the palace, remaining composed while others scramble.
Does not intervene or attempt to manage the situation when the music fails to start due to Mozart's absence, letting the Prince-Archbishop decide unchallenged.
Watches Mozart in amazement and disgust after Mozart rushes out disheveled to join his music.
Stands shocked and moves almost in a trance toward the door after inadvertently eavesdropping Mozart's Serenade.
Listens to Mozart's performance with amazement and transport, visibly fascinated rather than critical.
Steals toward the music stands, unable to help himself, indicating a sincere admiration for Mozart's talent.
Listens to Mozart's performance with amazement and fascination, recognizing the genius in the music despite personal disbelief.
Steals toward the music stands behind Mozart's back, unable to control his curiosity and fascination.
Does not intervene or support Mozart during Colloredo's humiliation.
Reflects on Mozart's Adagio with awe and admiration, acknowledging its divine quality and his own emotional response.
Lays down the score in silent, helpless fascination; does not engage with Mozart directly or appreciatively.
Examines Mozart's Serenade score carefully, appreciating its complexity and emotional depth; recognizes exceptional musical skill.
Expresses confusion and disbelief that Mozart, whom he regards as an 'obscene child,' could produce such divine music.
Sits decorously, listening silently during discussion of Mozart, without interjecting personal opinion or criticism.
Wears decorous black, remains quietly present among influential court members, indicating self-control and awareness of appropriate behavior in a formal setting.
Does not openly contradict or attempt to influence the Emperor's conversation about Mozart, showing restraint but possibly missing an opportunity to assert his position or expertise.
Offers a diplomatic and thoughtful response regarding Mozart, showing respect for both Mozart and the court's politics.
Welcomes servant Lorl into his room politely by answering promptly and allowing her in.
Thinks it is an interesting notion to keep Mozart in Vienna, making a calculated political observation that could infuriate the Archbishop.
Greets Fraulein Lorl warmly, thanks her and the baker sincerely, inquires about her well-being, and praises the macaroon gift.
Pleases himself by successfully playing through a complete line of the march and smiles, showing satisfaction with the musical result.
Interacts politely and gratefully with Lorl, showing social grace but not directly related to professional skill.
Writes and presents a March of Welcome to honor Mozart arriving at court.
Politely defers to the Emperor allowing him to try the March and expresses modesty calling it 'just a trifle'.
Writes a March of Welcome in honour of Mozart and presents it to the Emperor with humility.
Correctly and politely points out the Emperor's wrong note while he plays the march.
Does not intervene to correct or influence the scene despite being present; allows Mozart’s undisciplined behavior and the Emperor’s display to proceed without visible reaction.
Greets Mozart warmly with 'Such an immense joy. Diletto straordinario!'
Responds dryly to Mozart's elaborate bow and compliments with 'My pleasure.'
Greets Mozart politely and acknowledges his work with a measured, dry demeanor, showing control and restraint in social interaction.
Responds briefly and without enthusiasm to Mozart's elaborate compliments, indicating confidence and emotional control.
Politely asks the king what virtues he considers proper, expressing a desire to learn as a foreigner.
Interrupts the conversation politely to inquire about the moral virtues in Mozart's work, showing engagement and awareness of court expectations.
Laughs discreetly along with Italian faction at Mozart's criticism of Italian opera.
Remains silent while Mozart challenges and mocks Italian music tradition.
Engages in courtly conversation with subtle sarcasm and wit, showing cultural knowledge (Italy vs. Germany on love).
Is silent when Mozart plays music imperfectly and courtiers look to him for judgment but does not speak up or correct Mozart immediately.
Watches Mozart perform with a fixed smile on his face, expressing polite appreciation.
Sits silently, staring at his olivewood cross and quietly says 'Grazie, Signore.'
Greets Katherina Cavalieri politely and engages her in light conversation about gossip.
Watches Mozart's performance with a fixed smile, maintaining composure and control in public.
Sits quietly staring at his olivewood cross, seemingly distracted and not immediately responding to knocks.
Responds calmly and promptly when finally addressing the knocks and visitors.
Engages in polite, light conversation with his student Katherina Cavalieri, showing social ease and control.
Tells Cavalieri directly and honestly that there is no part for her and cautions against involvement with the opera due to its setting in a Turkish brothel, implying concern for her reputation.
Responds to Cavalieri's request for an introduction with a noncommittal 'Perhaps,' showing reluctance to help rather than enthusiastic support.
Sits coldly watching the stage, emotionally detached from the performance.
Sits in a box coldly watching the stage while others are enraptured, showing detachment and control.
Mentally criticizes the singer's performance as 'ghastly scales and arpeggios, whizzing up and down like fireworks at a fairground,' showing sharp musical discernment and critical insight.
Stands respectfully among the court and receives the Emperor's praise for his pupil.
No intervention or support when Madame Weber and Constanze are denied access backstage and treated with insolence.
Agrees with the Emperor's critique to avoid conflict and maintain decorum despite Mozart's distress.
Agrees cautiously with the Emperor's criticism about Mozart's work having too many notes, showing deference but no strong defense.
Supports the Emperor's opinion by confirming the idea about the limits of the ear, indicating some understanding of music and court expectations.
Fails to challenge Mozart's claim that the criticism is absurd, showing deference and passivity in a tense moment.
Watches Constanze receive the Emperor's attention without intervening.
Watches Madame Weber faint and the ensuing awkward situation without intervening or offering help.
Observes Mozart and others carefully, showing awareness of the social dynamics at court.
Tells Mozart 'Don't bother!' when Mozart offers to help Katherina/Madame Weber after a performance.
Dismisses Mozart's intention to help Madame Weber by telling him 'Don't bother!'
Compliments Cavalieri sincerely on her performance and music ('You were sublime', 'Extremely clever').
Offers Mozart sincere congratulations on the marriage and music.
Does not respond to Cavalieri's rude and disrespectful remarks about Constanze and Mozart's marriage.
Holds Cavalieri as she cries in rage, providing physical support during her distress.
Prays and struggles internally with feelings of hatred and violent thoughts toward Mozart, trying to control them.
Harbors intense hatred and violent thoughts toward Mozart despite efforts to pray and forgive.
Kneels in desperation and prays intensely for Mozart to be sent away, showing his reliance on faith and persistence in seeking control over circumstances.
Expresses deep hatred and violent thoughts towards Mozart, revealing emotional turmoil and inability to restrain personal feelings.
Recognizes the complexity of God's plans and struggles intellectually with his own beliefs and moral tests, showing thoughtful reflection.
Allows personal jealousy and hatred to overwhelm rational judgment, which may compromise his effectiveness.
Bows respectfully to the Princess and addresses her with deference.
Expresses concern to the Emperor about avoiding suspicion of favouritism towards Mozart.
Suggests organizing a contest and a Committee to diplomatically handle Mozart's appointment.
Bows respectfully to the Emperor and the Princess, showing proper court etiquette.
Disguises disappointment about Mozart's potential appointment but maintains polite and controlled demeanor.
Proposes a clever plan to set up a contest and a committee to ostensibly protect the Emperor from accusations of favoritism, while influencing the outcome to his advantage.
Does not openly oppose Mozart's appointment but manipulates the situation subtly.
Pauses his lesson and promptly attends to an unexpected visitor, showing polite responsiveness.
Politely receives Constanze, expresses willingness to consider Mozart's work, promises to keep portfolio safe.
Refuses to look at the portfolio immediately, citing lack of leisure despite her request.
Listens attentively to Constanze's plea and circumstances, shows understanding by acknowledging their need and circumstances.
Politely receives Constanze and listens carefully to her plea on behalf of Mozart.
Takes the portfolio but declines to look at it immediately, citing lack of leisure.
Assures Constanze that the portfolio will be safe when left with him.
Shows some suspicion and curiosity upon learning Mozarts did not send Constanze.
Offers Constanze refreshment and explains the Roman chestnuts in a friendly manner, smiles at her, tries to lessen social distance by asking her not to call him 'Your Excellency'.
Insists subtly on Constanze returning to him to see 'other things you might like', showing interest in her and her music.
Takes and examines the music portfolio carefully, shows genuine curiosity and respect for the original music.
Offers refreshment with cultural and sensory detail, invites Constanze to relax, establishes rapport with warmth and attentiveness.
Carefully watches Constanze's reaction to the chestnuts, demonstrating attentiveness and social skill.
Engages in conversation to reduce social distance, showing emotional intelligence and confidence.
Insists on seeing Mozart's original music despite Constanze's reluctance, showing curiosity and strategic thinking.
Appears puzzled when seeing Mozart's music originals with no corrections, suggesting limits in his immediate understanding of Mozart's genius.
Recognizes Mozart's music as a divine, inimitable beauty and is deeply moved by it, showing reverence and awe.
Walks around his salon reading Mozart's music pages and drops them on the floor after reading, showing a distracted, almost painful struggle with his feelings.
Carefully studies Mozart's manuscripts, recognizing their intricate, flawless composition and profound beauty, showing his deep musical understanding and perceptiveness.
Despite recognizing Mozart's genius, Salieri reacts with visible emotional turmoil and seems unable to act decisively in the moment, shutting the portfolio abruptly.
Prays earnestly for a sign of God's favor, promising to act with respect and generosity toward Mozart and his wife.
Expresses bitter frustration and denies the existence of a merciful God, calling God a 'God of torture.'
Sits at his desk and prays passionately for inspiration, expressing deep longing and commitment to creating true music from God.
Expresses impatience and frustration with religious platitudes and challenges the idea of a merciful God, showing internal turmoil.
Allows Constanze into his apartment and listens to her despite evident tension; does not immediately reject or confront her.
Appears pale and very tight on seeing Constanze, suggesting discomfort or restraint.
Does not engage warmly or reciprocate Constanze's attempted friendly and warm manner; remains fairly silent and reserved.
Stirs himself to respond promptly to the knocking and instructs the servant clearly.
Appears pale and very tight when confronting Constanze, showing visible nervousness.
Stops Constanze from undressing, orders servants to show her out to protect her dignity amidst a difficult moment.
Reacts with distress and forcefully rejects Constanze's advance, causing her to become angry and humiliated.
Recognizes the inappropriateness of the situation with Constanze and immediately acts to stop it by ringing for the servants and ordering her out.
Reacts with visible distress and horror to the situation instead of calmly managing it, showing emotional overwhelm.
Vows to block and harm God's chosen instrument out of jealousy and resentment.
Burns a Christ figure in the fireplace as a symbol of his despair and anger toward God.
Vows to harm Mozart out of jealousy and resentment, demonstrating a deliberate and strategic decision to oppose his rival.
Unable to reconcile his faith with his professional jealousy, showing internal conflict and distress.
Makes inquiries about Mozart out of curiosity rather than malice.
Warns the emperor about Mozart not to be trusted alone with young ladies, based on a pupil's complaint of molestation.
Responds nervously but courteously to Mozart's unexpected visit; does not refuse to meet him.
Expresses sympathy and offers congratulations to Mozart, showing social grace and awareness.
Informs Mozart that the post has already been filled and that he cannot help now.
Shows distress about Mozart's situation but admits lack of power to change it at the moment.
Avoids attempting to intervene on Mozart's behalf despite his sympathy.
Offers Mozart a glass of dessert and listens patiently as he talks about his struggles.
Expresses concern about Mozart living in poverty and tries to understand his situation.
Responds supportively when Mozart insists he is not a fiend and denies having a daughter when asked.
Shows interest and encourages Mozart to share more about his new work.
Shows genuine interest in Mozart's secret with friendly banter and curiosity.
Offers to recommend a distinguished gentleman to help Mozart financially, mentioning the gentleman has a daughter.
Shows interest in Mozart's secret and tries to engage him in conversation, offering practical help with Mozart's finances by recommending a distinguished gentleman.
Tries to steer Mozart away from financial trouble by advising against becoming known as a debtor and offering a strategic social connection.
Engages in somewhat playful or ironic banter about patriotic feelings while discussing Italian cream cheese recipe, showing social intelligence and cultural awareness.
Does not intervene to help the shy girl or ease the parents' harshness; remains passive while others struggle.
Observes interaction quietly without mocking or harsh judgment, allowing Mozart to encourage the girl.
Does not intervene or attempt to help during the awkward situation with the girl and the dog, showing passivity rather than control.
No direct action or statement in this excerpt; observes Mozart's family situation silently.
No direct reference or action related to Salieri's competence in this excerpt.
Stands alone in a corner watching Mozart and others entering the party, then turns away hastily to avoid being seen by them.
Takes a mask quickly from a lady giving them out to guests and puts it on, preparing to join the party unnoticed.
Watches the game quietly from the doorway, does not intervene as others tease Leopold.
Observes the scene from the doorway quietly without intervening.
Remains absent or silent in a family playful scene involving Mozart, Leopold, and Constanze, showing no intervention or support.
Cautiously approaches the keyboard to watch Mozart's performance, showing interest in the social event.
Participates in the playful musical challenge by performing a mocking parody of the tune, deliberately making it offensively banal to provoke laughter.
Stares in pain and hatred at the memory of Mozart's mocking laughter and the removal of the crucifix, showing deep internal suffering but no outward reconciliation or warmth.
Internally curses God and vows to laugh at Him before leaving the earth, expressing bitterness and spite rather than forgiveness or kindness.
Sits silently, staring in hatred at the place where the crucifix used to hang, indicating deep internal conflict and determination to retaliate against perceived humiliation by God and Mozart.
Experiences inner humiliation and pain at Mozart's mocking behavior but does not lose composure externally.
Fails to confront Mozart directly or change the situation during Mozart's mockery, remaining passive while being mocked.
Sends a maidservant, Lorl, anonymously to offer services to Mozart and his family, providing help without revealing himself.
Offers sugared biscuits to Lorl, thanks her, praises her kindness, and pays her generously for information.
Enters Mozart's apartment after Lorl admits him; shows curiosity about Mozart's belongings.
Salieri enters Mozart's apartment with Lorl, showing interest and curiosity about Mozart's financial situation by listening carefully and having Lorl investigate.
Remains passive and only observes the situation in Mozart's apartment without taking direct action at this moment.
Enters Mozart's private workroom alone, treats Mozart's personal belongings with great reverence and awe, touching them gently as if they were beloved mementos.
Carefully examines Mozart's personal workroom and his manuscripts with deep reverence and attention to detail.
Demonstrates a strong emotional and intellectual engagement by recognizing the significance of Mozart's works and artifacts.
Does not take any immediate action or attempt to disrupt, showing restraint and thoughtful analysis rather than impulsivity.
Remains silent and does not intervene while Mozart warmly interacts with his father and the Emperor
Shares information about Mozart's new opera with the Director and Bonno, engaging cooperatively.
Informs the Director about Mozart's new opera project, specifying the controversial subject 'The Marriage of Figaro' based on a banned French play.
Claims to have seen the manuscript but avoids disclosing the source or location.
Does not speak up or intervene during the conversation about Figaro and Mozart's opera ideas, remaining silent while others express concerns.
Observes and participates in court discussions about Mozart's work, showing awareness of political sensitivities.
Does not interrupt or challenge Mozart's confident explanations about his innovative musical techniques.
Remains silent and does not intervene during Mozart's disrespectful outburst against traditional themes and the court, indicating a strategic choice to avoid confrontation.
Says they should help Mozart and protect him against the Emperor's anger.
Passively observes censorship of Mozart's ballet by the director without intervening.
Affirms that there is a ballet in the third act of Figaro, showing his detailed knowledge of the opera.
Does not intervene or contradict when Orsini-Rosenberg enforces the Emperor's order against ballet in operas, indicating a cautious or strategic omission.
Listens attentively to Mozart's plea and responds calmly, offers to intervene with the Emperor on his behalf.
Light-heartedly withdraws Mozart's kiss from his hand and jokes, making Mozart giggle and feel at ease.
Mentions that he said nothing to the Emperor later on, implying he did not follow through or help as promised.
Remains calm and comforting when Mozart is hysterical and desperate.
Recognizes the political realities of the opera director's power and proposes addressing the issue with the Emperor, showing strategic thinking.
Assures Mozart with gentle humor and grace, diffusing tension and maintaining confidence.
Later reveals to the audience that despite his promises, he took no actual action with the Emperor.
Obeys the Emperor's decree to remove the ballet despite its negative impact on the performance
Responds calmly and respectfully to the Emperor’s questioning without protest
Calmly and confidently explains to the Emperor that the ballet was removed due to the Emperor's own regulation, maintaining composure in a tense situation.
His reaction to the Emperor's surprise attendance is limited to a composed explanation, showing control but no immediate initiative to manage the disruption.
Watches the performance of Figaro with tears on his cheeks, moved by the music and the scene of forgiveness and love on stage.
Reflects on Mozart's music as a miracle and expresses bitterness about his own defeat in comparison.
Expresses admiration for Mozart's Figaro as a bold and brilliant wonder despite his own opposition.
Remains emotionally moved and tearful in his box while watching Mozart's performance, indicating a deeply personal but composed response.
Acknowledges his own defeat openly and insightfully, showing self-awareness and understanding of artistic merit.
Listens sympathetically to Mozart's complaints about the opera's reception.
Advises Mozart to accept the public's rejection gracefully.
Gives honest but gentle critique on why the opera failed, explaining the Emperor's short attention span and the audience’s reaction.
Expresses admiration for Mozart's work, calling it marvelous and the best opera yet written.
Responds to Mozart’s invitation to teach him with mild irritation (‘fuming’).
Bows respectfully to Mozart and expresses honor at sharing music with him.
Looks at Mozart with immense pleasure and notices Mozart's enthusiastic applause.
Internally questions Mozart's genuine enthusiasm for someone else's music, showing a hint of jealousy or suspicion.
Successfully composes and conducts a grand opera (Axur: King of Ormus) that receives deafening applause and strong audience approval, including the Emperor and other dignitaries.
Shows immense pleasure and pride in the reception of his work, indicating confidence in his artistic skill.
Appears momentarily unsettled or suspicious by Mozart's unexpected enthusiastic applause, showing self-doubt or insecurity.
Bows his head modestly when receiving the Emperor's medal and chain.
Raises a respectful and admiring woman (Cavalieri) up after she curtseys to him.
Moves eagerly to greet Mozart, acknowledging his presence warmly despite their rivalry.
While accepting widespread adulation from the crowd, selectively focuses on Mozart instead of the general praise.
Receives the Civilian Medal and Chain from the Emperor, honored as the brightest star in Vienna's musical firmament.
Composes utterly conventional and uninventive music, as noted in the description.
Maintains composure during the public accolade and acknowledges Mozart politely.
Salieri warmly invites Mozart by greeting him and showing eagerness to please him with his work.
Salieri smiles upon Mozart's praise, indicating sincere appreciation.
Responds to Mozart's praise with a calm, modest smile and continues the conversation smoothly.
Uses his influence to limit Don Giovanni's performances to only five in Vienna.
Secretly attends all performances alone, unable to help himself and worshipping the sound he alone seems to hear.
Recognizes the powerful emotional impact and innovation in Mozart's opera, including the symbolism of the Commendatore ghost invoking Leopold.
Experiences madness and internal conflict, describing himself as split in half by jealousy and admiration.
No direct action or statement present in the excerpt; Salieri remains absent and silent during Mozart's distress.
Admits Mozart is a lost cause, refuses to recommend him to anyone due to his behavior.
Agrees with Von Swieten's concerns about Mozart's situation, showing some acknowledgment of Mozart's difficulties.
Suggests a commission opportunity for Mozart to an 'appropriate person', potentially offering help despite Mozart's flaws.
Disguises himself with a menacing mask and cloak to approach Mozart covertly.
Commissions Mozart to write a Requiem Mass for a dead man who ‘deserved’ it but never received one, approaching Mozart directly.
Offers Mozart fifty ducats and another fifty upon completion of the Mass, insisting on secrecy and prompt work.
Turns away from Mozart after the offer without further engagement or encouragement.
Offers Mozart a secret commission with a clear payment and deadline, demonstrating control and planning.
Turns away immediately after the bargain, emphasizing secrecy and strategic distancing.
Dramatically reveals his plan to ensure Mozart's death and a public funeral spectacle, showing a calculated and ambitious scheme.
Composes the Requiem Mass for Mozart as a devoted friend, expressing deep passion and sublimity in the music.
Reflects with anguish on the act of killing Mozart, showing personal torment over his involvement.
Calms and soothes a frightened and tearful Lorl who is distressed about leaving her job.
Calms down a frightened and tearful Lorl, speaks to her to soothe and handle the situation.
Listens with concern to Lorl's fears about Mozart's condition and repeatedly asks questions to understand if Mozart is working on an opera.

Visits Mozart at night to request unfinished work; after Mozart begs for more time, Salieri insists sternly that the sooner he finishes, the better the reward, then leaves without further encouragement.
Pressures Mozart firmly to complete the composition quickly, offering a clear incentive and showing strategic mind in managing Mozart's output.
Appears intimidating and commanding, maintaining control of the interaction despite Mozart's hesitation.
Contemplates the situation silently, showing a measured and calculating demeanor.
Does not display emotional vulnerability or uncertainty; rather, behaves with confidence in the interaction.
Does not intervene or offer support during Mozart's obvious personal crisis and abandonment.

No direct action or statement from Salieri in the excerpt; his absence or omission to intervene or act while Mozart deteriorates could suggest a lack of immediate competence in dealing with Mozart's decline.
Sits in a theatre box watching The Magic Flute attentively alongside other citizens, demonstrating interest in contemporary music and opera.
Observes the stage attentively, notices the actor miming playing without sound, shows awareness of the problem, but hastily leaves his box instead of addressing the issue.
Steps forward to take care of the unconscious Mozart, offers his carriage, and physically carries him away respectfully.
Steps forward promptly to take responsibility for helping the unconscious Mozart, arranging a carriage and physically carrying him, despite the awkward situation backstage.
Helps the ill Mozart into a sedan chair and walks beside him through the cold night, then carries the lantern into Mozart's disheveled, cold apartment to aid him.
Lights candles to warm Mozart’s cold, poorly kept room and tends to him by helping him sit up, removing coat and shoes, and covering him with a coverlet.
Shows concern by asking about Mozart's wife and listens empathetically to Mozart’s complaints and fears.
Encourages and praises Mozart’s work sincerely, calling it sublime and him the greatest composer known to him.
Offers to answer the frightening knocking at the door despite Mozart's evident fear, showing protective intent.
Looks after Mozart, tells Schikaneder and the actresses Mozart is resting and reassures them.
Accepts the money from Schikaneder to give to Mozart without hesitation.
Moves to the door promptly when Mozart is alarmed, attempts to manage the situation by confronting the visitor Schikaneder, showing attentiveness and responsiveness.
Explains to Schikaneder that Mozart is sleeping and should not be disturbed, displaying calm and careful judgment to protect Mozart's condition.
Reassures Schikaneder that Mozart is all right despite exhaustion, controlling the narrative and preventing panic.
Tells Schikaneder he will inform Mozart about the successful reception and the money, showing responsible communication and advocacy for Mozart.
Passively accepts the money from Schikaneder to give to Mozart without objection or hesitation, demonstrating acceptance of practical help and financial support.
Delivers money to Mozart from the employer and encourages him to complete difficult work on a tight deadline.
Offers to help Mozart discreetly and collaborates with him to overcome a physical difficulty in composing.
Smiles at Schikaneder while being vaguely suspicious and thoughtful, indicating social awareness and strategic thinking.
Assists Mozart feverishly in writing down the Requiem Mass, showing attention and cooperation.
Engages sincerely in discussing the meaning of the text with Mozart, showing openness and thoughtfulness.
Efficiently assists Mozart by consulting the manuscript and accurately tracking the point to continue composing the Requiem.
Translates Latin text correctly and participates knowledgeably in theological discussion, showing understanding.
Appears fully engaged and feverish in desire to write dictated notes quickly and accurately, demonstrating focus and capability.
Collaborates patiently and attentively with Mozart, demonstrating expert transcription skills and willingness to follow Mozart's demanding instructions.
Labours to keep up with Mozart's instructions and asks for clarification patiently.
Writes feverishly, showing intense dedication and focus on Mozart's work.
Engages with Mozart despite Mozart's impatience and irritation.
Writes feverishly to keep up with Mozart's rapid musical dictation, showing effort and urgency.
Struggles to keep pace with Mozart's instructions, asking for clarification multiple times and appearing labored.
Confirms and clarifies musical details carefully before proceeding, demonstrating thoroughness and attention to detail.
Appears overwhelmed and reliant on Mozart’s repeated explanations, suggesting a lack of readiness for the complexity and speed Mozart demands.
Engages patiently and attentively with Mozart's musical instructions, responds enthusiastically and encouragingly.
Sits looking on in wondering astonishment as Mozart performs the Confutatis, attentively writing down Mozart's dictation despite Mozart’s exhaustion and poor health.
Assures Mozart he can keep working without rest, showing dedication and support to Mozart despite the difficult circumstances.
Sits looking on in wondering astonishment while Mozart sings, indicating admiration but also possible surprise or feeling overshadowed.
Writes assiduously and nonstop as Mozart urgently dictates music despite Mozart's exhaustion and illness.
Declines rest and insists he can keep working, showing dedication and endurance.
Tells Mozart 'I'm not leaving you' when Mozart asks him to stay while he sleeps.
Listens patiently as Mozart apologizes and asks for forgiveness.
Sleeps in cramped child’s bed next to Mozart, showing physical closeness and care.
Attempts to button his waistcoat ineptly to avoid looking improper when Constanze arrives, showing awkwardness but a respectful demeanor.
Explains to Constanze that Mozart is ill and that he has brought him home, being forthcoming and responsible.
Insists on staying with sick Mozart despite Constanze's clear refusal; attempts to take Mozart's manuscript away under pretense of assistance.
Reluctantly hands over the Requiem manuscript to Constanze despite his agony.
Stares stunned and silent when Constanze locks away the manuscript, showing a powerless reaction rather than anger or cruelty.
Respects Constanze's wish and prepares to leave despite mutual hatred, showing restraint.
Hesitates and shows extreme reluctance in handing over the Requiem manuscript despite being asked firmly, indicating internal conflict and lack of decisive action.
Shakes hands mournfully with Von Swieten at Mozart's funeral gathering, showing respect and shared grief.
Moves to assist Constanze (Mozart's widow) who is near collapse but is rejected as she seeks support from Cavalieri instead.
Weeps convulsively and tearfully in private, revealing deep emotional pain and vulnerability.
Confesses publicly to having poisoned Mozart’s life, seeking recognition for overshadowing Mozart even if damaging him, showing bitterness and a selfish desire for attention.
Attends Mozart's funeral despite emotional difficulty and adverse weather, showing commitment and respect.
Moves to assist Constanze in her distress but is turned away, revealing sensitivity to social dynamics and boundaries.
Openly confesses to poisoning Mozart's life, demonstrating emotional honesty but possibly undermining his own standing.
Accepts blame for ruining Mozart’s life despite others denying murder, showing internal conviction but also self-destructiveness.
Expresses deep bitterness and hatred towards God for Mozart's death and his own suffering; embraces infamy rather than obscurity.
Rejects pity and instead transfers it to others, showing no self-pity or appeal for sympathy.
